[[de Havilland DH.60 Moth|Gipsy Moth]] }} '''No. 4 Elementary Flying Training School''' (No. 4 EFTS) was a [[Royal Australian Air Force]] (RAAF) pilot training unit that operated during World War II. It was one of twelve elementary flying training schools employed by the RAAF to provide introductory flight instruction to new pilots as part of Australia's contribution to the [[British Commonwealth Air Training Plan|Empire Air Training Scheme]]. No. 4 EFTS was established in January 1940 at [[RAAF Station Mascot|Mascot]], New South Wales, and initially operated in conjunction with civilian flying organisations based at Mascot and [[Newcastle Airport|Newcastle]]. The school was disbanded in April 1942, and its operations transferred to [[No. 6 Elementary Flying Training School RAAF|No. 6 Elementary Flying School]] at [[Tamworth Airport|Tamworth]]. ==History== Flying instruction in the [[Royal Australian Air Force]] (RAAF) underwent major changes following the outbreak of World War II, in response to a vast increase in the number of aircrew volunteers and the commencement of Australia's participation in the [[British Commonwealth Air Training Plan|Empire Air Training Scheme]] (EATS). The Air Force's pre-war pilot training facility, [[No. 1 Flying Training School RAAF|No. 1 Flying Training School]] at [[RAAF Williams|RAAF Station Point Cook]], Victoria, was supplanted in 1940–41 by twelve elementary flying training schools (EFTS) and eight service flying training schools (SFTS).Stephens (2006), pp. 67–70[https://www.awm.gov.au/images/collection/pdf/RCDIG1070724--1-.pdf Gillison (1962), p. 111] The EFTS provided a twelve-week introductory flying course to personnel who had graduated from one of the RAAF's initial training schools. Flying training was undertaken in two stages: the first involved four weeks of instruction (including ten hours of flying) to determine trainees' suitability to become pilots. Those that passed this grading process then received a further eight weeks of training (including sixty-five hours of flying) at the EFTS. Pilots who successfully completed this course were posted to an SFTS in either Australia or Canada for the next stage of their instruction as military aviators.[https://www.awm.gov.au/images/collection/pdf/RCDIG1070724--1-.pdf Gillison (1962), pp. 106–109] [[File:RAAF Tiger Moth 1940 (AWM P02881.024).JPG|thumb|left|upright=1.28|Tiger Moth trainer in front of the De Havilland hangar at Mascot prior to delivery to the RAAF, 1940|alt=Biplane on tarmac in front of hanger marked "De Havilland Aircraft Pty Ltd"]] No. 4 Elementary Flying Training School (No. 4 EFTS) was formed at [[Sydney Airport|Kingsford Smith Aerodrome]], [[RAAF Station Mascot|Mascot]], New South Wales, on 2 January 1940, and came under the control of [[No. 2 Group RAAF|No. 2 Group]].RAAF Historical Section (1995), pp. 20–21Royal Australian Air Force (1939–45), p. 349 Its inaugural commanding officer was [[Squadron Leader]] A.W.L. Ellis. Mascot had been [[Sydney]]'s civil airport since 1920, and was home to several private aviation organisations.{{cite web|url=http://www.airforce.gov.au/raafmuseum/research/bases/mascot.htm |title=Mascot|publisher=[[RAAF Museum]]|accessdate=8 January 2016}}[https://www.awm.gov.au/images/collection/pdf/RCDIG1070476--1-.pdf Gillison (1962), pp. 72–73] It was the airfield's position as the hub of civilian flight instruction in New South Wales that led to it becoming the base for the fourth flying school the RAAF raised during World War II. The same principle was followed in basing [[No. 1 Elementary Flying Training School RAAF|No. 1 EFTS]] at [[Parafield Airport|Parafield]], South Australia, [[No. 2 Elementary Flying Training School RAAF|No. 2 EFTS]] at [[RAAF Station Archerfield|Archerfield]], Queensland, and [[No. 3 Elementary Flying Training School RAAF|No. 3 EFTS]] at [[Essendon Airport|Essendon]], Victoria. [[File:Clive Caldwell 1941 (AWM MED0177).JPG|thumb|right|[[Flight Lieutenant]] Clive Caldwell, a graduate of No. 4 EFTS who became Australia's top-scoring fighter ace of World War II, in the Middle East, December 1941|alt=Informal full-length portrait of uniformed man wearing peaked cap and smoking a cigarette]] The first training courses at No. 4 EFTS were not conducted under the auspices of EATS but by civil organisations under government contract. The instructors from these organisations were commissioned as [[Officer (armed forces)|officers]] in the RAAF. The flying school was divided into four [[Flight (military unit)|flights]]: "A" (training conducted by the Royal Aero Club of New South Wales), "B" (conducted by Kingsford Smith Air Services Pty Ltd), "C" (conducted by Airflite Pty Ltd), and "D" (conducted at [[Newcastle Airport|Newcastle]] by the Newcastle Aero Club). The training aircraft were [[de Havilland Tiger Moth]]s and [[de Havilland DH.60 Moth|Gipsy Moth]]s. All air cadets were subject to RAAF discipline, and the school's training program was directed by the commanding officer. The initial intake of twenty-four students arrived on 8 January 1940. Accommodation was severely limited at the new flying school: No. 4 EFTS headquarters was housed in the clubhouse of the Royal Aero Club, the base sick quarters utilised the [[Department of Civil Aviation (Australia)|Department of Civil Aviation]]'s casualty room, and cadets had to pay for their own rooms at the nearby [[Brighton-Le-Sands, New South Wales|Brighton-Le-Sands Hotel]]. No. 4 EFTS's strength as at 1 February 1940 was four officers, twenty-one [[airman|airmen]], one civilian, and twenty-four cadets. The second intake of twenty-four cadets arrived four days later.Royal Australian Air Force (1939–45), p. 351 The school's inaugural EATS course commenced on 29 April.Royal Australian Air Force (1939–45), p. 355{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article17668697 |title=Empire air scheme |newspaper=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]] |location=Sydney |date=29 April 1940 |accessdate=9 January 2016 |page=11 |publisher=[[National Library of Australia]]}} The government's contracts with the civilian organisations for flying instruction at Mascot and Newcastle were terminated during August 1940, and their aircraft—fifteen Tiger Moths and eight Gipsy Moths—were impressed by the RAAF. Airflite was engaged to provide maintenance.Royal Australian Air Force (1939–45), p. 363 On 18 November, an instructor was killed when he fell into a [[Randwick, New South Wales|Randwick]] street from a Tiger Moth performing a slow roll after his safety harness broke; neither he nor his student, who though badly shaken was able to land the plane, were wearing parachutes.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article17715776 |title=Fall from plane |newspaper=The Sydney Morning Herald |location=Sydney |date=19 November 1940 |accessdate=9 January 2016 |page=10 |publisher=National Library of Australia}} One Tiger Moth landed on top of another on 27 December; both planes were badly damaged but no-one was killed.Royal Australian Air Force (1939–45), p. 372{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article17700928 |title=Three planes damaged |newspaper=The Sydney Morning Herald |location=Sydney |date=28 December 1940 |accessdate=9 January 2016 |page=11 |publisher=National Library of Australia}} No. 4 EFTS's strength as at 1 February 1941 was twenty officers, 101 airmen, and sixty-two aircrew trainees.Royal Australian Air Force (1939–45), p. 375 Two Tiger Moths collided over [[the Lakes Golf Club]] on 6 April, killing the instructor and his pupil in one of the aircraft; the pilots of the other plane survived after crash-landing on the golf course.Royal Australian Air Force (1939–45), p. 379{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article8173606 |title=Two airmen killed |newspaper=[[The Argus (Melbourne)|The Argus]] |location=Melbourne |date=7 April 1941 |accessdate=9 January 2016 |page=5 |publisher=National Library of Australia}} Owing to urgent requirements to house elements of the [[United States Army Air Forces in Australia|United States Army Forces in Australia]] (USAFIA), No. 4 EFTS was disbanded on 24 April 1942, and its operations transferred to [[No. 6 Elementary Flying Training School RAAF|No. 6 Elementary Flying School]] at [[Tamworth Airport|Tamworth]], New South Wales.{{cite web|url=http://recordsearch.naa.gov.au/scripts/Imagine.asp?B=166516|title=Formation, Organisation & Movement – No. 1 Flying Training School|author=[[Department of Air (Australia)|Department of Air]]|date=1941–47|page= 71|accessdate=8 January 2016}} No. 4 EFTS's graduates included [[Clive Caldwell]], who became Australia's top-scoring [[Flying ace|fighter ace]] of World War II.Garrisson (1999), p. 30 ==Commanding officers== No. 4 EFTS was commanded by the following officers: {|class="wikitable" |+ !
